item.title: Beogram 4002 (5521): Adjusting Platter and Chassis
item.description:
The visual appeal of a Beogram 400x relies heavily on the platter’s alignment with its surrounding aluminum panels. A correctly aligned platter sits flush with these panels, allowing the black ‘ribs’ to stand out against a flat aluminum surface. Achieving this alignment is intricate, requiring several parameters to be perfectly adjusted. I’ve observed that a sensor arm that isn’t entirely parallel to the floating chassis often complicates this process. Both the service manual and my videos detail an adjustment procedure assuming the sensor arm’s parallelism...

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): Adjusting the Floating Chassis Height
item.description:
After adjusting the main platter bearing in a Beogram 4002 (5513) turntable, you’ll need to set the height of the floating chassis. The goal is to make sure the aluminum surface of the platter is level with the surrounding aluminum panels. You can adjust the height by turning the nuts on the leaf springs that hold the chassis and provide vibration isolation. Using an 8 mm hex wrench is recommended...

item.title: Beogram 4002 (5513): A New Arrival on Beolover's Bench
item.description:

My initial assessment showed that it was packaged very well, with some innovative methods used to protect it during shipping. item.title: Beogram 4002 (5523): A Second Beogram 4002 (5523) Arrived for some TLC - First Impressions
item.description:
A Beogram 4002 (5523) in need of restoration arrived with its MMC4000 cartridge still attached and transport locks disengaged, causing initial concern about potential damage. The foam meant to support the tonearm had deteriorated, leaving it to swing freely. Fortunately, the cartridge appeared undamaged, likely due to the tonearm’s light weight and protective tape.
